introduction.p:
The learning objectives for this chapter are:
To understand and be able estimate and represent relationships between explanatory variables and a response variable.
To understand and be able least-squares regression.
To understand and be able to apply the concept of correlation.

section.title: Scatter Plots
section.p: A scatter plot shows the relationship between two quanitative variable. The values of one variable are on the horizontal axis, while the values of the second variable are on the vertical axis. Each data pair is represented by a point determined by the values on each axis. In a scatter plot, we look for patterns in the data as well as deviations.

example.p: Dr. J. is an avid cyclist. On a recent trip to Colorado, he recorded the work that he did on the bike (kilo joules), the intensity factor (IF), and the training stress score (TSS) for each ride that he did over a two week period (see Table). Roughly speaking, the intensity factor is the ratio of power to threshold power. That is, an intensity factor of 0.600 for a one-hour ride says that you are going at a rate of 60 of what you are capable of doing for one hour. The TSS is a number that tells you how hard you worked on that particular ride. We would like to predict both the IF and TSS from the work done. The scatter plot of work and TSS is in Figure.

section.p: A response variable measures the outcome of a study. An explanatory variable explains the response variable. In Example, the explanatory variable is work, while the response variables are the training stress score and intensity factor.

section.p: Two variables are positively associated if above average data of of one variable corresponds to above average data of the second variable. The variables are negatively associated if if above average data of of one variable corresponds to below average data of the second variable. The data (work and TSS) in Figure are positively associated.

section.title: Correlation
section.p: Correlation describes the strength of the linear relationship between two quantitative variables. More specifically, suppose that x and y are data for n individuals. That is, we have data sets \{x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n \} and \{y_1, y_2, \ldots, y_n \}. Furthermore, suppose that \overline{x} and s_x are the mean and standard deviation for the variable x, while \overline{y} and s_y are the mean and standard deviation for the variable y. We define the correlation r between x and y to be r = \frac{1}{n - 1} \sum_{i=1}^n \left( \frac{x_i - \overline{x}}{s_x} \right) \left( \frac{y_i - \overline{y}}{s_y} \right). Correlation is best computed using a computer or calculator.

example.p: The correlation between work and training stress score in Example is r = 0.9958, indicating a strong linear relationship between the two variables.

section.title: Least-Squares Regression
section.p: A straight line describing how a response variable y changes as an explanatory variable changes is called a regression line. We can use a regression line to make predictions. The least-squares regression line is the straight line that minimizes the sum of the squares of vertical distances of the data points from the line. The least-squares regression line is given by the equation \hat{y} = a + bx, where the slope b is given by b = r \frac{s_y}{s_x} and the intercept is a = \overline{y} - b \overline{x}.

section.p: Here is the R code for Example
